title: Capitalization
description: Rules for proper capitalization in Canadian English

content.mainText: Capital letters have three basic uses, of which nearly all others may be regarded as particular cases: (1) to give emphasis, as in official titles and initial words; (2) to distinguish proper nouns and adjectives from common ones; and (3) to highlight words in headings and captions.
content.explanation: In English the first letter of certain words is capitalized to give emphasis and to clarify sentence structure and meaning for the reader. This chapter gives rules to define which words require capitals, but editorial practice varies considerably on this subject, depending on the desired degree of formality, the intended readership and the organization's house style.

keyPrinciple.title: Consistency and Reference
keyPrinciple.content: In order to ensure consistency in your own style, follow the rules below, which apply to most general types of writing, and consult the Gage Canadian Dictionary, which gives the upper-case use of many words. Capitalization in specialized documents should be based on professional style guides.

rules.title: First word of sentence
rules.text: Capitalize the first word of a sentence or sentence equivalent:

rules.title: Direct quotations
rules.text: Capitalize the first word of a direct quotation that is itself a complete sentence:
examples: The candidates said, "We are in favour of a free vote on the death penalty."
rules.note: Do not use the upper case if the quotation is merely a sentence fragment or is worked into the structure of the sentence:
counterExamples: The candidates said that they were "in favour of a free vote on the death penalty."
rules.additionalNote: In quotations where historical, legal, documentary or scientific accuracy is crucial, reproduce upper-case letters as faithfully as possible. For more detailed information on quotations, see Chapter 8.

rules.title: Sentences in parentheses
rules.text: Capitalize the first word of a complete sentence enclosed in parentheses when it stands alone, but not when it is enclosed within another sentence:
examples: The speaker concluded by citing facts and figures to support her contention. (Details may be found on p. 37.)
but: The increasing scarcity of the species is attributable to overfishing (statistics will be found in the appendix), to acid rain and to other factors outlined in the report.

rules.title: Direct questions within sentences
rules.text: Capitalize the first word of a direct question within a sentence:
examples: The question to be asked in every case is this: Does the writer express himself or herself clearly?
rules.note: Consistently capitalize (or lower-case) parallel sentence fragments used as questions:
parallelExamples: Will farmers be taxed under this plan? Lumberjacks? Trappers?
Will farmers be taxed under this plan? lumberjacks? trappers?
rules.warningText: Do not capitalize words that normally introduce questions (who, why, when, how) when they stand alone as a verb complement:
rules.warningExample: He knew he had to meet the deadline. The question was how.

rules.title: After a colon
rules.text: Capitalize the first word after a colon if it begins a direct question (see 4.02(d) above) or a formal statement, introduces a distinct idea, or is followed by more than one sentence:
examples: There are several possibilities: For example, the Director General might resign.
The jury finds as follows: The defendant is guilty as charged on all counts.
Our position is clear: We will not permit new landfill sites in our region.
In conclusion, I answer the question asked at the outset: Revenues will be greater this year than in the past three years. However, they will not match expenditures.
rules.note: See Chapter 7 for further information on use of the colon.

rules.title: After question mark or exclamation mark
rules.text: The word following a question mark or exclamation mark may or may not be capitalized, depending on how closely the material it introduces is considered to be related to what precedes:
examples: What a piece of work is man! how noble in reason! how infinite in faculty!
Progress where? or, even more fundamentally, progress for whom?
What factors contributed to the decline of Rome? Did the barbarian invasions play a significant part?

rules.title: Truisms and mottoes
rules.text: Capitalize the first words of truisms and mottoes run into text:
examples: His watchword was Learn to write well, or not to write at all.
Her motto in life is Do unto others ... before they do unto you.

rules.title: I and O
rules.text: The personal pronoun I and the vocative O are always capitalized in English; oh is capitalized only when it begins a sentence or stands alone.

rules.title: Poetry
rules.text: The first word of a line of poetry is traditionally capitalized, but some modern poets do not follow this practice. It is therefore best to check the original and respect the poet's preference.

rules.title: Proper nouns and epithets
rules.text: Capitalize proper nouns and epithets that accompany or replace them:

rules.title: O' names
rules.text: When O' forms part of a proper noun, it and the first letter after the apostrophe are capitalized:

rules.title: Mc and Mac names
rules.text: When the particle Mc or Mac forms part of a name, the letter M is capitalized. Capitalization and spacing of the letters that follow may differ and individual preferences should be respected:
examples: McDonald or MacDonald or Mac Donald or Macdonald

rules.title: Articles and particles in names
rules.text: Individual preferences regarding the capitalization and spacing of articles and particles in French or foreign names should also be respected when they can be ascertained. The following are correct forms:

rules.title: Historical figures
rules.text: In the case of historical figures, treatment in English may differ from that in the original language, and no real standard appears to exist. Consistency in treating a particular name (such as Leonardo da Vinci, Luca della Robbia or Vincent van Gogh) is all that can be aimed for. In some cases, the most familiar form of the name omits the particle entirely:
rules.note: The Anglo-American Cataloguing Rules is an excellent source of such information.

rules.title: Nicknames and personifications
rules.text: Capitalize a nickname (a word or phrase used as part of, or instead of, a personal name). Similarly, capitalize names of fictitious or anonymous persons, and names used as personifications:

mainRule.text: As a general rule, capitalize an adjective derived from a proper noun or a name used adjectivally:
mainRule.explanation: Proper adjectives are associated with the person or place from whose name they are derived.

remoteAssociation.title: When association is remote
remoteAssociation.text: When this association is remote, the adjective becomes common and in most cases no longer takes a capital, as illustrated below:

verbs.title: Verbs derived from proper nouns
verbs.text: Verbs derived from proper nouns are also capitalized unless their association with the proper noun is remote:

warning.text: Check proper noun derivatives carefully, however. Usage in this regard is not standardized.

rules.title: Official titles to capitalize
rules.text: Capitalize the titles of international, national, provincial, state, regional and local governments; the titles of government departments and agencies and their organizational subdivisions; the names of boards, committees and royal commissions; and the Crown when it means the supreme governing authority:
examples: the Department of Citizenship and Immigration
the Federal Cultural Policy Review Committee
the Royal Commission on National Development in the Arts, Letters and Sciences
rules.note: Note that both the legal title and the applied title of a federal department are capitalized:
titleExamples: Department of the Environment = Environment Canada

rules.title: Short forms - when to use lowercase
rules.text: It is in the use of short forms that the greatest uncertainty arises. Short forms are normally written in lower case when used in a non-specific sense, when preceded by a possessive, demonstrative or other type of adjective, and when used adjectivally or in an adjectival form:
lowercaseExamples: We have formed a committee to study the matter.
Our section held its monthly meeting yesterday.
The Canadian (federal, provincial, present) government has issued a policy statement.
An interpretation of the departmental rules and regulations is required.
The question of parliamentary procedure was raised.
Unfortunately division practice proscribes such an approach.
The decision was based on government (governmental) policy.

capitalizedExamples.text: However, when short forms of government bodies stand for the full title and are intended to carry its full force, they are usually capitalized. This style is almost always used in in-house documents:
examples: The Government has adjourned for the summer.
The Minister's message was circulated throughout the Department

adjectivalUse.text: If the short title is a specific term which the organization shares with no other body within the government concerned, that title retains the upper case when used adjectivally:

rules.title: The word 'Government'
rules.text: The word Government is capitalized when it refers to the political apparatus of a party in power. It is lower-cased when it refers in a general way to the offices and agencies that carry out the functions of governing:
rules.capitalized: The Liberal Government introduced this measure.
rules.lowercase: It is government policy not to discuss matters before the courts.

rules.title: Plural forms
rules.text: Do not capitalize the plural forms of government, department, division, etc., even when the full titles of the bodies concerned are given:
examples: Representatives from the departments of Finance, National Defence and Natural Resources were present.

rules.title: Official names
rules.text: Capitalize the official names of organized churches (religious denominations, sects, orders) and their adherents, universities, school boards, schools, courts of law, clubs, corporations, unions, alliances, associations, political parties, etc.:
rules.note: The official capitalization is that used by the institution itself.

rules.title: Administrative subdivisions
rules.text: The names of administrative subdivisions of these institutions are also capitalized:

rules.title: Generic short forms in corporate writing
rules.text: A generic noun used as a short form of a title is often capitalized, especially in corporate writing:

rules.title: Specifying element only
rules.text: Capitalize short forms that use only the specifying element:
examples: This afternoon, Concordia and Western will play in the final.

rules.title: When NOT to capitalize generic short forms
rules.text: Do not capitalize generic short forms used in a non-specific sense, preceded by a possessive, demonstrative or other type of adjective, or used adjectivally or in an adjectival form:
examples: The university is our town's major employer.
Our family attended a Baptist church regularly.
She tries to attend all board meetings.
Only strict adherence to the party line was tolerated.
Every board of education in the province has adjourned for the season.

rules.title: Specific, unique institutions
rules.text: But, if the short form refers to a specific, unique institution, it retains the upper case when used as a noun or adjectivally:
examples: The Scouts held a rally over the weekend.
A city-wide Red Cross blood drive replenished the hospital's supply.

rules.title: Internal documents
rules.text: Documents intended for an internal readership often capitalize terms that would be lower-cased in writings of a general nature:
examples: He worked for the Company for almost forty years.
The document was forwarded to the Regional Office.

rules.title: Subsequent references
rules.text: In second and subsequent references, short forms may be treated generically and lower-cased:
examples: He was invited to address the Second Annual Conference on Biotechnology but declined because the conference was not sufficiently broad in scope.
She applied for a grant under the External Scholars Program, but only graduate students were eligible under the program.

rules.title: Plural forms
rules.text: Do not capitalize the plural of common nouns, even when the full titles of the bodies concerned are given:
examples: He held degrees from the universities of Saskatchewan and Toronto.
Candidates for the Liberal and Progressive Conservative parties attended the rally.

mainRules.title: Specific parties and movements
mainRules.text: Adjectives and nouns referring to the ideas, actions, documents and members of specific political parties, movements and groups are capitalized. Capitalization often helps distinguish these terms from the same words used descriptively:
capitalized: a Liberal policy paper (of the Liberal government or party)
a Progressive Conservative government (refers to the Progressive Conservative Party)

mainRules.title: The word 'party'
mainRules.text: Capitalize the word party when it is preceded by the official name of a political party, unless it is used as a generic term:
mainRules.capitalized: He was a member of the Social Democratic Party.
mainRules.lowercase: A new agrarian party was founded at the rally.

mainRules.title: General terms for movements
mainRules.text: General terms describing political movements and their adherents are lower-cased unless they are derived from proper nouns:

rules.title: Titles preceding names
rules.text: Capitalize civil, military, religious and professional titles and titles of nobility when they precede and form part of a personal name:

rules.title: Titles in apposition
rules.text: Capitalize all titles following and placed in apposition to a personal name, except those denoting professions:
capitalized: Clara Smith, Director of Public Affairs
Ron Irwin, Minister of Indian Affairs and Northern Development

rules.title: Titles as substitute for names
rules.text: Capitalize a title referring to a specific person and used as a substitute for that person's name, even if it is a short form:
examples: the President of the Treasury Board
According to the Assistant Deputy Minister, this is a unique agreement.
They discussed the matter with the Colonel.
The Archbishop made no further comment.

rules.title: Titles in plural or with indefinite article
rules.text: Do not capitalize spelled-out titles in the plural or titles preceded by an indefinite article:
lowercase: the lieutenant-governors of Quebec and Ontario
rules.exception: the Member for Winnipeg North Centre

rules.title: Abbreviated titles in plural
rules.text: Capitalize abbreviated titles in the plural:
examples: We met Profs. Sami and Nicolet.

rules.title: Modified titles
rules.text: Do not capitalize titles modified by a possessive or other type of adjective, or by an indefinite article:
examples: They discussed it with their colonel.
They discussed it with the former ambassador.
They discussed it with the Canadian prime minister.
They discussed it with a member of Parliament.

rules.title: Title vs. role
rules.text: Capitalize titles only when they refer to a specific person; do not capitalize a term that refers to a role rather than a person:
examples: As prime minister [that is, while occupying a certain position], Lester Pearson introduced the new Canadian flag.
The production manager [any person who occupies that position] assigns schedules.

rules.title: Occupational titles
rules.text: Occupational titles used descriptively are normally followed by a complete personal name. They should not be capitalized in writing for general readers, although corporate requirements and the expectations of a specialized readership often result in a more liberal use of capital letters:

rules.title: Adjectives from titles
rules.text: Do not capitalize adjectives derived from titles unless they are part of a title:

rules.title: Titles of respect
rules.text: Capitalize titles of respect and forms of address, even when used in the plural:

personifications.title: Vivid personifications
personifications.text: Capitalize vivid personifications and metonymic nouns:
examples: the Chair (the person in charge of a meeting or assembly)
the Crown (the person or agency representing a king or queen)

abstractions.title: Abstractions in ideal sense
abstractions.text: Abstractions are sometimes capitalized when used in an ideal sense. As general concepts, however, they are lower-cased:
capitalized: We know that Justice is blind.
Beauty is truth, truth beauty—that is all / Ye know on earth, and all ye need to know. —John Keats

mainRule.text: Capitalize family appellations only when the name of a person follows, when they are unmodified, or when they are used in direct address:
capitalized: I met Mother at the theatre.
Tell me, Son, where you have been.
lowercase: This is my aunt, Sarah Vick.

mainRule.text: Capitalize nouns and adjectives referring to race, tribe, nationality and language:

allophoneRule.text: Do not capitalize the word allophone, which refers to a person whose first language is neither English nor French and which is used with specific reference to Quebec.

wordVariations.title: Variable forms depending on meaning
wordVariations.text: The form of some words may vary depending on the meaning:

examples.capitalized: Aborigine (one of the indigenous peoples of Australia)
Pygmy (member of a group of African peoples)

indigenousPeoples.title: Aboriginal peoples terminology
indigenousPeoples.text: Capitalize the singular and plural forms of the nouns Status Indian, Registered Indian, Non-Status Indian and Treaty Indian, as well as the terms Aboriginal, Native and Indigenous when they refer to Aboriginal people in Canada.
indigenousPeoples.note: The terms Aboriginals and Natives are not used as proper nouns. When Aboriginal, Indigenous and Native are used as adjectives, note the following noun forms:
examples: Aboriginal persons, Aboriginal people (more than one person)
Aboriginal peoples (two or more Aboriginal groups)
Representatives from three Aboriginal peoples were present.
Any Native person in Alberta is eligible under this program.
The conference could not have succeeded without the help of almost a thousand Indigenous people from all over Saskatchewan.
indigenousPeoples.referenceNote: For further information on the representation of Aboriginal (Native) peoples in written communications, see Chapter 14.

languagesRule.text: In keeping with 4.11 above, capitalize the names of languages. Do not capitalize the names of other disciplines when used in a general sense. Capitalize them when used to refer to school subjects or the names of particular courses:
examples: This university requires French as a prerequisite.
He reads articles on economics and biology in his spare time.
but: He passed with a 'B' in History this term.
She is taking Chemistry 101 and Economics 406.

degreesRule.text: Do not capitalize the name of a degree in general references, but do capitalize it when it follows a person's name and is written in full:
examples: Janet is earning her master's degree
He holds a Master of Arts degree from McGill University.

academicYears.text: Do not capitalize terms designating academic years:
examples: She held two jobs during her senior year.

gradeRule.text: Capitalize grade when followed by a number or letter:

mainRule.text: Capitalize the names and nicknames of military bases, forces and units of all sizes and of exercises:

dndNote.title: Note
dndNote.text: In Department of National Defence documents, the specific part of an exercise name is written entirely in upper case, e.g. Exercise SILENT DEFENDER.

generalReferences.text: Use the lower case for general and informal references:

mainRule.text: Capitalize the names of types of aircraft, the names of makes of cars and other modes of transportation, and the names of individual ships, locomotives, spacecraft, etc.:
examples: HMCS Donnacona (italics for the name; roman type for the abbreviation)

italicsReference.text: See 6.07 for further information about the italicization of such names.

mainRule.text: Capitalize the official names of professional, academic and military medals, awards, honours and decorations:

shortForms.text: Most common-noun short forms are lower-cased:
examples: No award was given this year.
shortForms.exception: However, they may be capitalized if the reference is clear:
shortForms.exceptionExample: The Prize [Nobel Peace Prize, mentioned in a previous sentence] was her reward for a lifetime of effort.

mainRule.text: Capitalize the official and familiar names of major sporting events and trophies:
examples: the XXVI Olympiad; the Olympic Games

shortForms.text: Capitalize the short form in subsequent references:
examples: The second Series game will be played today.
Her team won the Cup last year as well.

sections.title: Time references and historical periods and events

mainRule.text: Capitalize the names of months and days, of holidays and holy days, of historical and geological periods and events, and of parliamentary sessions:
examples: The First Session of the Thirty-second Parliament

seasonsAndCenturies.text: Do not capitalize the names of the seasons, centuries or decades unless they are personified or are part of special names:
capitalized: the Roaring Twenties (name of an era)

religiousEvents.text: Capitalize the names of events recorded in sacred writings and of historical events with a strong religious dimension:

specificVsGeneral.text: Terms that refer to events and periods are often capitalized when they refer to specific events or periods and lower-cased when used in a general sense:

timeZonesReference.text: For the use of capitals with time zones, see 1.22.

mainRule.text: Capitalize nouns and adjectives designating literary, philosophical, musical, religious and artistic periods, movements and styles when they are derived from proper nouns:

lowercaseRule.text: Otherwise, such terms are lower-cased except when it is necessary to distinguish a style or movement from the same word used in its general sense:

generalPrinciple.text: The same principles apply to religious terms as to general vocabulary. Writers should resist the temptation to overcapitalize.

rules.title: Religious adjectives and verbs
rules.text: Capitalize most adjectives and verbs derived from the names of organized religions:

rules.title: Holy and revered persons
rules.text: Capitalize the names and titles of holy and revered persons:

rules.title: Theological concepts
rules.text: Capitalize unique theological concepts:

rules.title: Non-religious sense
rules.text: Do not capitalize derived terms that are not used in a religious sense:
examples: She is very catholic in her literary tastes.

rules.title: Religious writings and documents
rules.text: Capitalize the titles of religious writings and documents, special prayers and devotional canticles, creeds and confessions:

rules.title: Names of deities
rules.text: Capitalize names, synonyms and personifications of deities and other supernatural beings:

rules.title: Common noun usage
rules.text: Do not capitalize such words used as common nouns:
examples: The adoring public regarded the film star as a god.

rules.title: Derivatives
rules.text: Derivatives of these terms are normally lower-cased, as are similar terms used metaphorically:

rules.title: Pronouns referring to deities
rules.text: Capitalize personal pronouns that refer to deities when they are used as proper nouns, but do not capitalize relative pronouns:
examples: Trust in Him whose strength will uphold you.

rules.title: Pagan deities
rules.text: Do not capitalize the words god and goddess when they refer to pagan deities, but capitalize the names of the deities themselves (Baal, Woden, Zeus).

rules.title: Heaven, hell, etc.
rules.text: Do not capitalize words such as heaven, paradise, purgatory, nirvana, happy hunting ground, devil and angel when used in a non-religious sense:
lowercase: After his wife died he went through purgatory.
capitalized: Many Buddhists seek to attain Nirvana.

rules.title: Official geographical names
rules.text: Capitalize the names of countries, regions, counties, cities and other official and specified political, administrative and geographical divisions and topographical features:
examples: the Ontario Region (sector of the government department)

rules.title: Generic terms as short forms
rules.text: Capitalize a generic term when it is an accepted short form of the proper noun:

rules.title: Generic terms in general sense
rules.text: Do not capitalize a generic term such as city, county, state or province when it precedes the proper noun or stands alone, unless it is used in a corporate sense:
lowercase: She lives in the city of Regina. (place)
I have travelled all over the province of Ontario. (place)
The states of Switzerland are called cantons.
the newly created state of Palestine
capitalized: Buy Province of Ontario bonds. (provincial government)
The City of Regina took him to court. (municipal government)
The State of New York has revamped its social assistance programs. (state government)

rules.title: Plural generic terms
rules.text: Do not capitalize a generic term used in the plural unless it is part of a geographical name:

rules.title: Compass points
rules.text: In general, do not capitalize the names of compass points or similar descriptive terms unless they have taken on political or other connotations or form the titles of administrative regions:

rules.title: Variable terms
rules.text: Some terms are capitalized when they refer to specific regions and lower-cased when used descriptively:
examples: the East Coast but the east coast of Nova Scotia

mainRule.text: Capitalize the official names of specific buildings, monuments, squares, parks, etc.:

genericUse.text: Do not capitalize words describing these features when they are used generically, in names that are not official, or in plural forms:

mainRule.text: Capitalize the names of planets and other astronomical bodies and configurations. Capitalize earth, sun and moon only when they are mentioned in relation to other planets or heavenly bodies:
examples: Mercury is closer than the Earth to the Sun.

genericParts.text: Do not capitalize generic words forming part of the name of a celestial object:

mainRule.text: Capitalize the scientific name of a phylum, order, class, family or genus, but not common names or the epithets referring to a species or subspecies, even if they are derived from proper names:
examples: the species Sporotrichum schenkii (second word denotes species)
The jaguar and the lion are members of the family Felidae.

properNounsInCommonNames.text: Capitalize proper nouns modifying a common name, except where usage has established the lower case:

reference.text: See 6.11 for rules governing the italicization of biological classifications.

chemicalElements.title: Chemical elements and compounds
chemicalElements.text: In text, do not capitalize the names of chemical elements and compounds:

chemicalSymbols.title: Chemical symbols
chemicalSymbols.text: The capitalization of chemical symbols should follow standard practice:

medicalConditions.title: Medical conditions and syndromes
medicalConditions.text: Do not capitalize the names of conditions, syndromes and the like, but capitalize a personal name that forms part of such a term:

infectiousOrganisms.title: Infectious organisms
infectiousOrganisms.text: Capitalize the names of infectious organisms but not the names of conditions based upon such names:
examples: People attacked by Salmonella are likely to suffer from salmonellosis.

drugNames.title: Generic drug names
drugNames.text: Do not capitalize the generic names of drugs:

mainRule.text: In scientific terms composed of a common noun preceded by a proper noun, an adjective derived from a proper noun, or a proper noun with an apostrophe s, capitalize the adjective or proper noun but not the common noun. Do not capitalize the names of laws or theories or the names of minerals, particles or elements derived from personal names:

specialCase.text: Note that certain personal names begin with a small letter:

tradeNames.title: Trade names
tradeNames.text: Capitalize trade names of drugs and any other manufactured products unless they have become established as common nouns:

referenceNote.text: To determine proper usage, check the Canadian Drug Index or your dictionary.

highTechProducts.title: High-technology products
highTechProducts.text: Some industries, especially in the high-technology field, use capital letters within the name of a product. The names of all such terms and products, including those of computer languages, should be capitalized according to the manufacturer's preference:

genericUsage.title: Generic usage of trade names
genericUsage.text: Wherever possible, do not use trade names as generic nouns or adjectives. For example, write adhesive tape, not Scotch tape. Some words, such as frisbee and realtor, are commonly used as generic terms, but they are in fact copyrighted. The word Aspirin is trademarked (and capitalized) in Canada, but not in the United States.

mainRule.text: Capitalize only the word Celsius when writing the names of SI/metric units in full. When using symbols, capitalize all those based on personal names and the letter L for litre:

prefixes.text: Capitalize the symbols for the prefixes from mega to exa. The symbols for the others remain in lower case. Consistency is important here because the letters m and p are both used in symbols for two different prefixes.

mainRule.title: Capitalization in titles
mainRule.text: In English titles of books, articles, periodicals, newspapers, plays, operas and long musical compositions and recordings, poems, paintings, sculptures and motion pictures, capitalize all words except articles, conjunctions of fewer than four letters, and prepositions of fewer than four letters. These exceptions are also capitalized when they immediately follow a period, colon or dash within a title and when they are the first or last word in a title:
examples: How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying (book)

prepositionsAsOtherParts.text: Words that are normally prepositions are capitalized when they help form another part of speech:

shortTitles.title: Short titles
shortTitles.text: In short titles, capitalize words that would be capitalized in full titles:
examples: Appleton's General Guide to the United States and Canada, Illustrated With Railway Maps, Plans of Cities, and Table of Railway and Steamboat Fares, for the Year 1891 (full title)
I read about it in the News.

originalTypography.text: Even if some words appear in all capital letters on the title page, capitalize only initial letters, except in specialized bibliographies that must reflect the original typography.

ancientManuscripts.title: Ancient manuscripts
ancientManuscripts.text: Titles of ancient manuscripts are capitalized, even if the titles were assigned in modern times:

frenchTitles.text: See the Appendix for capitalization of titles in French.

hyphenatedCompounds.title: Hyphenated compounds in titles
hyphenatedCompounds.text: In titles containing hyphenated compounds, always capitalize the first element. Capitalize the second element if it is a proper noun or proper adjective or if it is as important as the first element:

sections.title: Parts of a book or document

rules.title: Major divisions
rules.text: Capitalize references to specific parts of a document. These include certain common nouns in the singular when they are used in text references with numbers or letters indicating place, position or major division in a sequence. Capitalize a letter following such a term:

rules.title: Minor subdivisions
rules.text: Do not capitalize minor subdivisions such as page, note, line, paragraph and verse:

rules.title: Sections in laws
rules.text: Do not capitalize section when used for part of a law or set of regulations, but capitalize it if it refers to a large subdivision of a report, book or other document:

rules.title: General references
rules.text: Do not capitalize words referring to parts of a book when they are used in a general sense, are preceded by modifiers, or are in plural forms:
examples: The theory will be discussed in the next chapter.
The appendixes outline other migration patterns.
Even Miller's extensive bibliography is not complete.

rules.title: Cross-references
rules.text: Capitalize cross-references within a book when they refer to a particular section:
examples: Further readings are listed in the Bibliography.
See the Appendix for urban statistics.

rules.title: Informal references
rules.text: Informal references to chapter and topic titles may be capitalized and written without italics or quotation marks:
examples: His topics included Northern Travel, Survival on the Road, and Basic Maintenance.

marginHeadings.text: In headings that begin at the margin, capitalize only the first word and any other words that require capitals in their own right.

centredHeadings.text: In centred headings, capitalize all words except for articles (unless they begin the heading) and any conjunctions or prepositions of fewer than four letters. Prepositions that are an inseparable part of the verb should also be capitalized.

sections.title: Terms indicating time or numbered sequence

mainRule.text: Capitalize common singular nouns and abbreviations followed by a date, number or letter to denote time or sequence, or for the purpose of reference:
examples: It's Day 15 of the election campaign.
The shortest route from Toronto to Montréal is along Highway 401.

idiomaticExpressions.text: Some idiomatic expressions containing common nouns followed by a letter or number are also capitalized. The numbers in such expressions are often spelled out:

introduction.text: Point-form lists make it easier for the reader to understand how the elements are related. Grammar and syntax determine the internal capitalization and punctuation of the initial letters of items in lists. It is more important for lists to be logically understandable and syntactically consistent than to look alike.

syntacticallyRelated.text: If the lead-in to a list is syntactically related to the points that follow, as in this list,
rules: do not capitalize the first words of items within the list, and
except for the bullets or dashes, punctuate as if the entire sentence were not in point form.

capitalizedLists.text: Items in lists are sometimes capitalized. This list illustrates one possible set of conditions:
conditions: It is made up of complete sentences, which do not depend on the lead-in sentence fragment and which end with a period.
It contains points that are more easily grasped separately than together.

lowercaseItems.text: Incomplete sentences or single words entered as points in lists are normally lower-cased:

example.leadIn: Four issues are related to the economics of healthy housing:
example.note: Note that there is no period at the end of the list.

rules.title: Common nouns in legal contexts
rules.text: Some common nouns referring to parties to an action, the names of documents or judicial bodies are capitalized:
capitalized: The Court (meaning the judge) sustained the objection.

rules.title: Official names of legal documents
rules.text: Capitalize the official names of treaties, agreements, legal codes, pieces of legislation and other official documents, as well as their official short forms:

rules.title: Short forms
rules.text: Short forms are normally capitalized only when they constitute proper nouns or refer to a document of great significance:
capitalized: An appeal was launched under the Charter (full name: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms).

lowercase.text: Do not capitalize short forms when they are used in a general sense, as adjectives or plurals, or with modifiers:
examples: Farmers objected to some of the treaty provisions.
Parliament discussed the new white papers before it adjourned.
Under this act, a subsidy was offered to transportation companies.

rules.title: Pending and defeated legislation
rules.text: Do not capitalize general references to pending and defeated legislation:
examples: Parliament is discussing a new Privacy act.

mainRule.text: Use capitals for the first word and all nouns in the salutation of a letter, but only for the first word in a close:

properNouns.text: A proper noun or adjective in a hyphenated compound retains the capital:

prefixesAndSuffixes.text: In general, do not capitalize prefixes or suffixes added to proper nouns:
examples: The President-elect will tour the mid-Atlantic States in an American-made car.

modifyingElements.text: Do not capitalize the second element of a compound if it simply modifies the first or if the hyphenated elements make up a single word:

partOfCorporateName.text: Capitalize the when it is part of a corporate name:

adjectivalUse.text: Do not capitalize the when it is used adjectivally:
examples: The Minister answered the Globe and Mail reporter.

frenchArticle.text: The French definite article should be retained if it is part of a corporate name, and the should not precede it. If the French article is not part of the official title, replace it with the:
withEnglishArticle: a representative of the Office des professions du Québec

mainRule.text: Capitalize a single letter used as a word, whether hyphenated or not:
